Love playing this game split-screen. There are frustrating parts while learning the mechanics, but those quickly turn into humorous challenges.

A fun little puzzle platformer to play with a few friends once or twice, but after that most people just stop, and those who don't either treat it as a social game and go server hopping, conversing with other players, or seek to get better at it, as it is a very speedrun-able game. In my many hours of funny clay people game, I have found that it is best to be one of those people who either just stopped playing all together or turned it into a 3d forum, as they often have the best experience, and that getting really good simply gives you a feeling of isolation from a majority of the player base and leaves you with feelings of inferiority knowing that there will always be someone vastly better than you.

Over all 8/10 with friends, 6.5/10 alone.

I can't recommend Human: Fall Flat enough â€“ it's pure fun and positivity packaged into a delightful gaming experience. This game its so funny if playing party with friends or another player.

I just beat this game for the first time and I'm crying. 
This is one of the best games of all time and it deserves 100% of the attention it got. I remember first playing this some time in 2016 or 2017, back when I was only around 9 years old. I would play with my best friend at the time, David, and sometimes I'd play with my brother. It was one of the most fun games we played, and since my best friend moved away a few years ago, this game holds an extremely special place in my heart. Earlier today, I realized that even though I've played hundreds of hours across Xbox, Nintendo Switch, and PC, I've never actually seen the ending to the game. I decided that I had nothing better to do and decided to finally see the ending after so long. I had no idea how emotional I would be when i beat it, but after 7 years it made me cry like I've never cried to a game before. I am still tearing up at all of the memories this game gave me with my best friends and family, and I don't think I would be who I am today without it.

The game is incredible, besides the challenges given to you in each scenario, it is completely funny when you play with some friends, also it is a really good game to play when you are just trying to relax and laugh.

Human: Fall Flat is an absolute riot of fun, combining physics-based hilarity with open-ended creativity. The game's charmingly awkward protagonist stumbles and flops through surreal environments, turning every mundane task into a slapstick adventure.

The open-world design allows for endless possibilities, encouraging players to experiment with solving puzzles and completing challenges in their own zany ways. The multiplayer aspect amplifies the chaos, turning cooperative tasks into a symphony of laughter and collaboration.

The physics engine, while intentionally clumsy, adds an unpredictable and comical element to every action. Maneuvering your character may seem challenging at first, but it quickly becomes part of the charm, leading to unexpected and hilarious outcomes.

The game's minimalist aesthetic complements its whimsical nature, and the soothing background music enhances the overall laid-back atmosphere. The level design is ingenious, presenting players with puzzles that require both thought and experimentation.

Human: Fall Flat is a testament to the idea that gaming should be about joy and laughter. Its unique blend of physics-based antics and cooperative gameplay makes it a standout experience for friends looking to share a good laugh. Whether you're solving puzzles or tumbling through the world with friends, Human: Fall Flat is a delightful adventure in awkwardness that guarantees smiles and laughter throughout.
i like the game thats it its funny

I like this game somewhat, it's fun. I've completed it, it was fun. I've played some extra levels, some were fun, but not all.

What I don't like is:
- the character is too wobbly, sometimes it's pretty hard to control
- some puzzles can be very obscure
- the devs just keep adding achievements to the game for no good reason

The last one is the reason I'm "review-bombing" the game (although one review won't matter much). I'm tired of going back to an old game I'm not particularly fond of just to get 1-4 achievements added together with a level from the workshop (I can use workshop, you know?). What I do like is having games I have 100%-ed remain 100%-ed.

As a 50-year-old single father of two, life's challenges often felt like insurmountable obstacles, especially after the tragic loss of my beloved wife. Grieving, I found solace in the virtual world of Human Fall Flat, a whimsical game that unexpectedly became my lifeline.

Through its charming puzzles and quirky physics, Human Fall Flat offered me not just a distraction, but a new perspective on life. As I navigated the game's whimsical landscapes alongside my children, laughter replaced tears, and joy slowly began to fill the void left by loss.

With each puzzle conquered and each silly mishap shared with my kids, I rediscovered the simple pleasures of companionship and play. Human Fall Flat became more than just a game; it became a catalyst for healing and a beacon of hope for brighter days ahead.

In the end, Human Fall Flat taught me that even in the darkest of times, there's always a glimmer of light waiting to guide us back to happiness. And for that, I'll forever be grateful.

I first played this game back in 2018 originally for my Xbox, Then on 2020 I got this game on steam, The game's open-world layout, which lets players explore a range of surreal settings full of creative obstacles, is one of its best features. The clever and erratic puzzles demand a combination of strategy and imagination to solve. Every replay is a different journey because of the interesting depth of gameplay added by the freedom to approach barriers in whatever way you choose. Coordinating with friends or other players online adds a hilarious and chaotic dimension to the experience. The physics-based interactions and the unexpected outcomes of cooperative efforts make for some of the most entertaining gaming moments I've ever had. The game's whimsical essence blends perfectly with its appealing and minimalistic art design. The game maintains a visually captivating aesthetic from beginning to end thanks to the charming character design and inventively designed different environments. Although the controls are purposefully shaky to match the physics-based gameplay, they soon become clear and contribute to the overall fun. Experimenting with various movements and actions becomes part of the enjoyment, and the learning curve is gratifying. a need for everyone looking for a fun and hilariousÂ gaming experience. Its unique blend of cooperative gameplay, creative riddles, and peculiar physics sets it apart from other indie games.

Devs/Publisher pulled a really nasty move and silently removed Linux support.

Not only removing it, but entirely breaking it by walling off Linux users to play with Win/OSX users due to version checks.
Could be fixed if the Linux depot would be deleted, but that is apparently too hard.

Now to play again with other platforms, Linux users have to force Steam to download the Windows version and use Proton.

I'm not against the decision, it's understandable that more platforms are a pain to a small team, but this could have been handled extremely better than it has been.

"Human Fall Flat" is a very.. odd title (in a good sense). The game has gained a very large following in the past 7 years, but this popularity will not affect my criticism. I absolutely love the silly rag-doll style this game has and it's puzzle aspect is really well done. I've been playing this game for years on console and i'm coming up on 10 hours on Steam spent on this game in two days. I've really been grinding the achievements, so far I have 70/122 achievements completed and I haven't gotten bored of the grind, so far it seems like a relatively fun and mildly hard game to 100% but the challenge keeps it interesting. Keep up the great work, amazing updates, and maps No Brakes Games, and Curve Games!!!

[h1] Human: Fall Flat - Where Friends Make the Difference [/h1]



[list]
[*]Quirky Physics-Based Fun: Human Fall Flat brings a unique, physics-based approach to puzzle-solving and platforming, creating an environment where creativity and experimentation thrive.

Charming and Unconventional Design:
[*]The game's whimsical art style and character design contribute to its charm, making it a visually appealing and lighthearted experience.

Solo Struggles:
[*]Playing Human: Fall Flat solo can be a bit lackluster. The puzzles, while enjoyable, lack the same level of excitement and laughter that arises when playing with friends.

[*]Multiplayer Mayhem:
The true magic of Human: Fall Flat reveals itself in online multiplayer. With friends, the game transforms into a chaotic and hilarious adventure, turning even the simplest tasks into moments of shared laughter.

[*]Cooperative Puzzle Solving:
The puzzles in multiplayer mode often require teamwork and coordination. Solving challenges together enhances the gameplay experience, fostering a sense of camaraderie among players.

[*]Endless Creativity:
The open-ended nature of the game allows for creative problem-solving. Playing with friends opens up opportunities for innovative and often unconventional solutions to puzzles.
[/list]

The levels are beautifully designed; the graphics are nice; I also appreciate how physics work in this game. It would be a pleasure to explore the levels and to find alternate solutions to the puzzles if the character were easier to control. However, the janky control just turns exciting adventure into frustrating gameplay and stops me from playing any further than several levels. This is a deal-breaker considering that the game is a physics platformer. What a shame! Maybe playing with friends would make the control less unbearable, but I certainly will not recommend it as a single player game.

I usually enjoy these sorts of intentionally difficult to control games. Octodad, Surgeon Simulator, theyâ€™re fun games where fighting the controls is a big part of the enjoyment, Human Fall Flat tries for the same thing, but IMO fails. The controls are way more frustrating than fun, and the whole thing feels less like a game and more like something for streamers to monetise.

If youâ€™re just a regular person wanting to play a fun and funny game, even with friends, thereâ€™s WAY better physics based games out there than this one.

Imagine it's 1997 and Diablo's expansion just dropped and your dad picked it up after work for you, and it's sitting on the table in front of you, but the deal is you have to finish all your homework before you can play. And you have like 3 hours worth of math and social studies projects to finish.

That's this game except the homework never ends and there is no payoff

Still gradually working my way through levels on this. I paid less than a fiver and have enjoyed this for quite a few hours and I expect quite a few more (though I haven't spent as many 'active' hours as the counter seems to think - not sure what's going on there).
It's simple, but still challenging to solve the physical puzzles, and the engine often surprises me in how convincingly things behave.
I've found quite a few ways to shortcut or detour around problems, and seem to have managed to skip past some game areas altogether. Not sure if those tricks are intentional, but all part of the fun anyway.

The game is entertaining and engaging, perfect for repeated play. Its humorous gameplay and intriguing challenges keep you hooked and wanting more. Enjoy the unique experience of playing with well-designed mechanics and an easy-to-use interface.

For over 7 years, I may have lost the very first excitement when I first met this game. I was no more dumb and awkward. In exchange, I received so many friends to play around with, messing everything up is more interesting than solving all the puzzles on my own. Now I'd like to go to random lobbies and help those freshman pass those levels and give them a hand when they are about to fall. I'm gonna share my very first excitement to them, and tell them how amazing this game is.

As time goes by I noticed that I tend to play multiplayer games just to hang out with some friends rather than to compete and see my stats change.

Human: Fall Flat is an excellent choice for this kind of gaming sessions. The gameplay is simple yet very hard to master, and the game has charm written all over it. Even after playing for 10 hours, it is still hilarious to see one of my friends just miss a hard jump or see the physics of the characters completely mess up.

In all of the co-op sessions we had so far, we had a lot of fun. For this reason, Human: Fall Flat earns a very easy recommendation even at full price.

EDIT: Not to mention, the game is being constantly updated with new levels for free - it truly is a labour of love!

I played this game a lot back in 2019 when I bought it. I never played it alone, but always in split screen with controller and my mate. And I remember enjoying every single minute of this game.

Besides cleverly designed levels there is also a thriving steam workshop community. And every few months there is a new level added to the core game which usually comes from the workshop community. So in these few years that I wasn't playing, there was a lot of levels added. So I decided to try them out.

And it just came back to me how great this game is. Of course the core mechanic is controlling a stiff human that needs to climb around and move objects. It is a physic puzzle game - the genre I am very fond of. The human isn't that hard to control. You can move, jump and grab stuff with left and right hand using triggers on your controller. When using a controller, the position of your hand depends on the angle of camera. This is probably the most annoying aspect of the game. For example: when you want your human to extend hands to the sky (something you will do a lot) you need to point the camera to the sky. Considering that it is a third person view, you will clip into objects a lot when doing it. When playing in split screen, it can help a lot looking at the other player's screen to provide different angle on your character. Thats's a coop right there.

But for me the controls never were a big issue. The game luckly doesn't ask you to do very crazy platforming or hard to execute movements. Rather it makes you figure out the way to get over the obstacles. It is a puzzle game after all. And levels are insanely imaginative and beautifully themed. One of the most memorable levels is for sure water in which you steer the big ship. And "dark" where you resurrect frankenstein. Or "Ice" where you go skiing. And the game is filled with such beautiful discoveries and easter eggs.

This game hardly has any music. A beautiful melody is usually triggered when hitting a checkpoint. Not bad to be honest, but richer OST would definitely be welcome.

With that said I cannot recommend this game enough, especially for the multiplayer experience. It is clever and lovely at the same time. It is for sure one of my all time favourites..

It's a great game for irregular multiplayer session with friends. One of the reasons it works so well is that all levels and puzzles can be approached with varying degrees of asynchrony. 
Want to tackle something together and help each other out? Sure! Want to explore something different alone while the other players do something else? Sure! Need to go afk for a few minutes to make a tea without feeling stressed to miss out? No problem, either. 

Very relaxed, and also very fun. I would recommend it to anyone who enjoys puzzles based on a physics engine.

Human Fall Flat transforms your controller into a comedy remote, orchestrating moments of sheer hilarity as you navigate an intentionally wonky world. It's the kind of game where even the simplest task, like opening a door or climbing a ladder, becomes a sidesplitting performance. As you grapple with physics-defying puzzles and try to coordinate your character's flailing movements, you'll find yourself in a perpetual state of chuckles. The beauty lies in its absurdity; it's a playground where chaos reigns and laughter thrives. Each stumble, flop, and misstep is a comedic gem, making "Human Fall Flat" an experience that'll leave you grinning from ear to ear long after you've closed the game.

An incredible game, Human Fall Flat is a co-op physics platformer where you throw your man around and grippy grab things with your hands to operate mechanisms and climb to the end of levels. The level sizes range from small to massive, there is an incredibly in-depth character creator that allows you to paint on your lil guy, and it's 8-player online. This is one of the most fun online experiences I've had in a long time. The way the players move is so oddly realistic, you'll find yourself just watching your teammates attempt to do basic things.

Human: Fall Flat is an excellent little puzzle game. This game has the potential to last anyone a long time, as they make their way through every puzzle and level. As well, it has a ton of achievements, which is great for a completionist like me that likes to see their progress through them. And although the physics can become irritating at some points, it's always possible to overcome. I can't wait to spend 24.7 more hours on this game!

It's like Dark Souls but because of puzzles and "parkour". 
You try again and again, fail, fall, struggle until you complete one puzzle. And then there is the next one.
The game also lacks a bit of interesting gameplay mechanics for this length. You do pretty much the same at the end of the game as you did at the beginning. 
Also even though the game features a local-coop mode there is absolutely no reason to play it in co-op. All the levels are designed to be completed solo so one of the players will probably get bored if the other one will be taking the initiative or will be better at climbing.
The music and the narrator's commentaries are very charming but there are so little of them in the game...

But otherwise - the game is good. A breathe of fresh air among all those conveyor made games. I'm not sure if I would be replaying it again or buying the second part, but the time I've spent in this game I definitely not regret spending.

Human: Fall Flat - Unpredictable Physics Fun

Playing "Human: Fall Flat," I couldn't help but draw comparisons with games like Ubisoft's "Grow Home" and Boneloaf's "Gang Beasts." This quirky physics-based puzzler seems to follow in the same wobbly footsteps as these titles, but it manages to carve out its own unique charm.

In "Grow Home," you guide a wobbly robot named BUD as he uses physics to solve puzzles and climb a giant plant. "Gang Beasts" features blobby characters wobbling around, employing physics for multiplayer brawls. Now, in "Human: Fall Flat," you control a blobby character named Bob, who's equally unsteady on his feet and uses physics to tackle puzzles and navigate through various rooms.

At first, I was a bit skeptical. The initial levels felt derivative and somewhat clumsy compared to its peers. Bob, with his blank expression and featureless appearance, didn't immediately win me over like BUD did in "Grow Home." However, my opinion took a turn once I got the hang of climbing.

Bob's animations, initially clumsy, suddenly appeared endearing as I learned to manipulate his independently controlled arms for climbing. The whole process, from jumping a gap to raising Bob's hands above his head and then running toward the edge, became oddly satisfying. It was as if I'd stumbled upon the secret to making Bob lovably daft, and I found myself rooting for him.

But here's where "Human: Fall Flat" veers into subjective territory. While BUD in "Grow Home" had a clear goal of reaching the top of a giant plant, Bob's objectives are less defined. You're not entirely sure where you're going, except that each sprawling level eventually leads to your plummeting to the next one. For BUD, it felt urgent and desperate; for Bob, it's more casual, albeit entertaining. Whether you find this patience-testing or not largely depends on your mood at any given moment.

The game's ability to let you improvise solutions is undeniably rewarding. Some puzzles have multiple solutions, and the game's open-ended approach often leads to unexpected ways of solving them. It's immensely satisfying to think outside the box, even if the game sometimes interprets your antics as being stuck and drops a hint.

My affection for "Human: Fall Flat" oscillated between delight and annoyance. The later levels, with their vibrant colors and character, provided a lovely contrast to the initial blandness. Yet, I occasionally found myself frustrated by Bob's unwieldy movements and wished for more straightforward controls.

In the end, "Human: Fall Flat" exudes charm and offers genuine fun, as long as you can endure its unpredictably goofy physics. It's a natural evolution of the "Grow Home" concept, successfully making it their own. And that climbing animation? It's simply delightful.

This is not a good game unless you prefer frustration to fun. The puzzles are enticing, the world seems fun and pretty at first. But then you start to realize the difficulty in this game does not come from challenging puzzles or interesting twists, but instead from clunky controls. Its not that the jumps or lifts or lock or anything like that are difficult to figure out, but that the controls regularly don't work properly. You often cannot tell what you are grabbed on to, its difficult to control whatever you've picked up or are moving. 

This difficult part of a parkour-esque game should be in solving what to do and where to go or in working to execute difficult jumps or climbs. It should not come from broken clunky faulty controls. Idky this isn't standard thinking in 2023.

The core of the game is good, but the recent levels are becoming more and more bugged and, because of this, seemingly carelessly implemented. Port, the currently latest level, literally cannot be finished due to a bug unless you know the wall climbing exploit, and even then it's tricky. One and a half months later and people still run into this issue.
I don't know whether the levels come directly from the workshop or are made/overhauled by the devs, but if a level is put into the game as official content with achievements and all, is it too much to ask that it at least works?

The fact that new achievements pop up every few months means that you never get to keep the 100% achievement badge for too long, so if you're like me and aren't that interested in the game itself anymore (I bought the game 7 years ago) but would like to keep the achievement badge, it's even more frustrating if the levels are bugged or boring.

I played lot of the game on Xbox Gamepass, and finally got my own copy on Steam for good price and still enjoying it as ever. There might be moments where it just annoys mebut at end of day I had great laughs playing this - both solo and with a friend or two.

At the time of this post, I've gotten every single achievement there is and yet I'm planning to play with friends still as well check the workshop levels out so I feel like there's lot of things to do in this game, and I honestly can recommend this to anyone.

The game also goes for very, very good price in sales too.

[h1]Overall[/h1]

Human Fall Flat is a great execution of a flawed idea. That idea is to combine wily ragdoll physics/controls with a 3D puzzle platformer, which makes for an immeasurably frustrating experience. Unfortunately, that single reason made this review "not recommended" because it's the soul of the game. It's a shame because the dev team created a solid product in many other aspects.

Its strongest feature is that it's a good game to play with young kids. They don't need to be a master of the controls to play along, nor do they need to "keep up" to progress with you to the next area.

[table]
[tr]
	[th]Pros[/th]
	[th]Cons[/th]
[/tr]
[tr]
	[td]ğŸŸ© Sufficient challenge and variety in the puzzles
ğŸŸ© Plethora of community levels and content
ğŸŸ© Good to play with young kids
ğŸŸ© Dedicated devs
ğŸŸ© Gentle piano soundtrack
[/td]
	[td]ğŸŸ§ [b]Frustrating control of ragdoll character[/b]
ğŸŸ§ Multiplayer more frustrating than single player
ğŸŸ§ Levels are too long in most cases
[/td]
[/tr]
[/table]

[h1]Ragdoll physics / Controls[/h1]

Let's start with the very core of my complaint. This is one of the most annoying games I've played in my life and it's entirely due to the design of the controls combined with the ragdoll physics. Those who have played Gang Beasts will find this one familiar. While the controls/physics feel more refined and functional than in Gang Beasts, this approach is in the wrong type of game. In Gang Beasts, it's more fun because it's a casual, button-mashing, brawling, party game. But in HFF, it's a nerve-wracking nightmare because you actually need to [i]do[/i] things in this one besides just wildly hurling yourself at your opponent. A certain level of precision is required.

For those not familiar with Gang Beasts let me put it this way: The gameplay is like having all the side effects of being the drunkest frat boy at the kegger, but with none of the fun of being intoxicated. You can't walk straight. Your arms flail around with the accuracy of wet noodles, and then you're expected to perform seemingly simple but practically frustrating feats. It's fun if you're the drunk, but not if you're the one controlling the drunk person, and that's what this game feels like. You have control of your character, but only [i]some[/i] control.

If any of these tasks sound appealing, then this game is for you:
[list]
[*]spending a couple minutes simply trying to plug in wires, pick up something off the ground or flip a switch, because your character can't keep his freaking arms steady
[*]spending five minutes trying to stack a couple blocks that easily topple because they behave like styrofoam in a low-g environment
[*]spending ten minutes trying to climb a wall because your floppy dude can only inch his way up a few pixels at a time. It's about 30 button/stick movements just to climb up three feet of wall.
[/list]

Ill give them credit, I used a controller in ways I've never used before. So if that sounds fun to you, then by all means, jump right in. Looking at the other reviews, I'm clearly in the minority here.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2949433534

[h1]Puzzles[/h1]

The puzzles are decently challenging; more than a few are clever. Every level had something unique to accomplish in it. A few puzzles made me stop and think for a bit, however there wasn't anything so complicated that I was totally out of ideas and had to come back another day. It is well done in this regard, but not a brain buster.

Keep in mind that the hard part isn't solving the puzzles, it's executing your ideas. That is where you'll spend most of your time. You may know full well that you need to stick a key in the door to open it, but you'll spend a full 60 seconds just trying to get the freaking key in the door. Other times you may spend five minutes doing the wrong thing because you'll believe "I'm just not getting the pieces together right", only realizing after many attempts that it was never going to work.

There's a loophole built-in that allows you to skip over some puzzles. Your character can grip just about any surface. This means that instead of solving a puzzle to get over a wall properly, you can spend ten minutes making your character climb over a wall or obstacle. It's extremely tedious, but it can be less frustrating than some of the puzzles. Sometimes I looked at a puzzle and thought "screw this" and just opted to slowly climb over a wall rather than be bothered trying to do some feat of precision with imprecise controls. It's nice that this loophole exists, but should this kind of thing exist in a [i]good[/i] game?

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2949432318

[h1]A few positive notes[/h1]

If I haven't scared you off yet, you'll be pleased that there is quite a bit of content. The early reviews comment on it being short, but it is anything but short now. Since it's original release the devs have continued to roll out new levels every couple of months. There are a total of 23 official levels now. On top of that, the workshop area is fairly vibrant with many quality fan made levels.

There is also quite a bit of customization you can do for your character. There are many preset combinations, but for the creative types out there you can go into great detail to assemble, draw and paint your own unique character. Importing of webcam images is supported too.

The soundtrack is a soothing solo piano, which is actually quite good.

[h1]Multiplayer[/h1]

All of the levels are possible to complete as single-player, but it's a tad easier to complete multiplayer as long as you have a competent teammate. While I'm glad they didn't hamstring single-player, it makes multiplayer pointless. Which is ironic, because this game is meant to be primarily played multiplayer.

I've tried both local multiplayer and online multiplayer. Online play was a little laggy. Incompetent and sometimes counterproductive teammates made a frustrating game even more frustrating. Most people I played with either got in the way or weren't helping. You really have to cross your fingers every time you join a lobby and hope others are on the same level as you or better.

[h1]Good for kids?[/h1]

I'll admit, this is a good game to play with a young kid. I went through nearly all of the game this way. As mentioned before, all levels are designed to be complete-able by a single player, so if your kid is too new/young to gaming to contribute you can still carry your kids through all the levels (as long as they don't actively sabotage your efforts). They don't need to master the controls as long as they have fun tagging along. Furthermore, you aren't attached to them like a ball and chain. They can get distracted and wander off, and it will not slow you down in the least. My five year old enjoyed it, but she was mostly just wandering around, while I was mashing buttons attempting to solve the puzzles. It was fun for her!

[h1]Achievements and completion time[/h1]

It took me 54 hours total to get through all 23 levels, 115 achievements and play a few community workshop levels. Yes, I actually did play through this entire game, earned 100% of the achievements and still left a negative review. I have this nasty habit of wanting to finish things I start, but I digress.

Other than that, the achievements are an ok balance between challenge and obtainable. Some achievements are rarely earned (0.1%) but that's only because they are related to levels that were recently released (thus few people have had a chance to play them). None felt impossible, and only one was grindy ("Speedrun").

The levels take over one and a half hours each to get through the first time, which to me was too long. It was a big relief when each level was finally over.

Human Fall Flat is a physics based puzzle platformer which has some cool ideas and good execution, some pros: The game has really good coop, the game has some really cool things put up on the steam workshop, such as Peter Griffin in the backrooms. Cons: the game's puzzles don't do it for me, they feel really tedious and unrewarding, unlike the platforming parts which are fun and rewarding, I would recommend playing this game with friends, and buying it on sale.

Human Fall Flat is a downright awesome game. When you have finished a level or the game, you can always go back and solve every section a different way because there are two (or more) ways to complete every level. 

Edit 4 years later: I know it says that I only have 400+ hours on this game, but I have been playing for even longer than that. I used to spend every waking moment playing this game on Xbox before I re-bought it on steam for the community workshop. This game is my all-time favorite and I will always come back to it.

Amazing game for anyone wanting to experience something new and interesting. It has many levels and puzzles that I really like. It's quite a simple game, too and has no really advanced graphics (not in a bad way). Quite fun to play with friends.

My only downsides are:
1. There is no cross platform play (e.g People who bought Windows store version cannot play with people who bought Steam version)
2. Characters can sometimes glitch out and have for example one leg gone (or when I was playing online, my character got totally stuck and could not move)
3. Most of the "levels" that other people make are in a foreign language and cannot be read by somebody who does not know said foreign language. I would like for the game to have an inbuilt level editor, so that players can edit levels more easily and so that level making is more accessible, especially to platforms outside the Steam version, since for PS4 and Windows store version, there is no community levels.

While I see how [i]Human: Fall Flat[/i] could be a lot of fun in multiplayer, especially doing custom levels, the singleplayer gameplay just doesn't do it for me. I realize it's a physics game and that this is intentional, but the player character's lack of maneuverability is inherently frustrating. While the puzzles aren't conceptually difficult, it's not particularly fun to be stuck in a level for a technical reason, even though you've identified the route out and the mechanism by which to get there. It's also easy to get physically stuck on or behind objects. In a group, that frustration can sometimes be funny.

That's not to say this game isn't worthwhile or interesting. I didn't find the puzzles particularly engaging to begin with, but this game isn't really about complicated puzzles: it's about failing to do basic human motion properly (and having fun with that). Admittedly, it is fun at first, even in singleplayer. The physics engine and its whole "flinging yourself around" approach is amusing. It was neat to think about individually coordinating each of your hands to grab objects, climb, move things, etc. Perhaps this is how toddlers feel every day.

Still, it didn't do it for me. An additional pain point is that the way the camera moves is at best disorienting and at worst nausea-inducing. (I don't typically get motion sickness in video games either.) I wasn't engaged by the narrator's remarks and the soundtrack felt out of place. The graphics are intentionally low-poly, and some of the levels are a bit cute, but I felt the plainness was lacking some artistic spark. Performance was perfectly good though!

If you want a game that lets you fool around with your friends, this is it! If you want a more technically playable puzzle game, there are more suitable options out there. Personally, just not my thing.

Pros: Multiplayer can be occasionally silly; levels can be fun for players that like moderately difficult physics puzzles (or above moderately difficult easter egg achievements); level themes are varying; customizable avatars

Neutrals: Has physics that can range from pleasant to very frustrating (especially for the poorly designed player levels); online players can either be helpful or actively mess around, which mostly doesn't happen

Cons: Puzzle mechanics across some levels can feel repetitive; Their is no level or lobby builder tool; can't report players for inappropriate messages or avatar skins; can't block players from joining your lobby

You will not find Portal-esque, beautifully designed, one-elegant-solution kinds of puzzles here. Instead, the physics allow for such a multitude of possible (inelegant) solutions, none of them feel rewarding, and only result in "phew, glad we made it through that stupid part" sorts of feelings. The humour isn't very good either. Wouldn't really recommend this to anyone except the biggest lovers of silly physics-type stuff.

Human: Fall Flat - Whimsical Physics Puzzles for Hilarious Creativity

Rating: â˜…â˜…â˜…â˜…â˜†

Human: Fall Flat, released in 2016, invites players into a charming and surreal world of physics-based puzzles and goofy escapades. Developed by No Brakes Games, the game offers a unique blend of puzzle-solving, creativity, and lighthearted humor that results in an entertaining and often hilarious gameplay experience.

The central character, Bob, is a customizable and delightfully clumsy humanoid who stumbles and tumbles through a series of dreamlike levels. The game's physics-driven mechanics are intentionally wonky, leading to comical and unexpected interactions with the environment. This intentional quirkiness is at the heart of the game's charm and appeal.

Each level of Human: Fall Flat is a sandbox of possibilities, tasking players with navigating intricate puzzles and obstacles. The game encourages creative problem-solving, allowing players to manipulate objects, climb surfaces, and experiment with the environment in their quest to reach the exit. The open-ended nature of the puzzles means that there are often multiple solutions, fostering a sense of accomplishment and ingenuity.

The cooperative multiplayer mode enhances the enjoyment, allowing you to tackle the challenges with friends. The chaotic and collaborative nature of solving puzzles together often results in hilarious outcomes, from inadvertently launching each other into the air to trying to coordinate complex maneuvers.

Human: Fall Flat's visual design is simple yet endearing, with its charmingly minimalistic environments and quirky character animations. The dreamlike settings, from ice caves to industrial complexes, offer a visually diverse and captivating backdrop for the puzzling adventures.

The game's humor is derived from the absurdity of the physics interactions and the ragdoll-like movements of the characters. Watching Bob stumble, flop, and flail through the environment is a constant source of amusement, and the unpredictability of the physics can lead to genuinely laugh-out-loud moments.

Despite its strengths, Human: Fall Flat does have its limitations. The intentionally awkward controls and physics mechanics, while a defining feature of the game, can also lead to occasional frustration when precision is required. Additionally, the lack of a comprehensive narrative or progression system may limit its long-term appeal for some players.

In conclusion, Human: Fall Flat offers a delightful and entertaining blend of physics-based puzzles, creativity, and humor. Its charming visuals, open-ended gameplay, and cooperative multiplayer mode make it a standout choice for players seeking a unique and lighthearted gaming experience.

If you're looking for a game that will tickle your funny bone and challenge your problem-solving skills in a whimsical and imaginative world, Human: Fall Flat is a delightful choice that promises laughter, creativity, and hours of engaging puzzle-solving fun.

My name is Walter Hartwell White. I live at 308 Negra Arroyo Lane, Albuquerque, New Mexico, 87104. This is my confession. If you're watching this tape, I'm probably dead, murdered by my brother-in-law Hank Schrader. Hank has been building a meth empire for over a year now and using me as his chemist. Shortly after my 50th birthday, Hank came to me with a rather, shocking proposition. He asked that I use my chemistry knowledge to cook methamphetamine, which he would then sell using his connections in the drug world. Connections that he made through his career with the DEA. I was... astounded, I... I always thought that Hank was a very moral man and I was... thrown, confused, but I was also particularly vulnerable at the time, something he knew and took advantage of. I was reeling from a cancer diagnosis that was poised to bankrupt my family. Hank took me on a ride along, and showed me just how much money even a small meth operation could make. And I was weak. I didn't want my family to go into financial ruin so I agreed. Every day, I think back at that moment with regret. I quickly realized that I was in way over my head, and Hank had a partner, a man named Gustavo Fring, a businessman. Hank essentially sold me into servitude to this man, and when I tried to quit, Fring threatened my family. I didn't know where to turn. Eventually, Hank and Fring had a falling out. From what I can gather, Hank was always pushing for a greater share of the business, to which Fring flatly refused to give him, and things escalated. Fring was able to arrange, uh I guess I guess you call it a "hit" on my brother-in-law, and failed, but Hank was seriously injured, and I wound up paying his medical bills which amounted to a little over $177,000. Upon recovery, Hank was bent on revenge, working with a man named Hector Salamanca, he plotted to kill Fring, and did so. In fact, the bomb that he used was built by me, and he gave me no option in it. I have often contemplated suicide, but I'm a coward. I wanted to go to the police, but I was frightened. Hank had risen in the ranks to become the head of the Albuquerque DEA, and about that time, to keep me in line, he took my children from me. For 3 months he kept them. My wife, who up until that point, had no idea of my criminal activities, was horrified to learn what I had done, why Hank had taken our children. We were scared. I was in Hell, I hated myself for what I had brought upon my family. Recently, I tried once again to quit, to end this nightmare, and in response, he gave me this. I can't take this anymore. I live in fear every day that Hank will kill me, or worse, hurt my family. I... All I could think to do was to make this video in hope that the world will finally see this man, for what he really is.

Discovering "Human Fall Flat" has been an absolute revelation for me at 80 years old. As someone who's witnessed the world evolve in countless ways, I never expected to be so amazed by a video game. The sheer fun and joy it brings, even in my older years, have left me pleasantly surprised.

In my younger days, we couldn't have imagined exploring virtual worlds or interacting with characters as we do now. But this game has managed to captivate me in ways I never thought possible. Playing as an adorable, bobble-headed character, I navigate through charming landscapes filled with puzzles and laughter.

When my grandchildren first introduced me to "Human Fall Flat," I must admit I was skeptical. How could something seemingly simple hold my attention? However, I soon discovered that the game's delightful graphics and physics-based challenges provided endless entertainment and moments of laughter.

Seeing my digital avatar stumble and fumble, much like my own real-life movements, is both funny and endearing. But what truly surprised me is the sense of achievement I feel when overcoming difficult puzzles or finding creative solutions. It keeps my mind sharp and reminds me that learning and growth never stop, no matter one's age.

One of the most heartwarming aspects of the game is the co-op mode, where I can play with my grandchildren. They patiently guide me through the virtual world, just as I guided them through life when they were young. The shared experience strengthens our bond and creates treasured memories.

"Human Fall Flat" is a testament to how technology can bring people of all ages together and provide endless enjoyment. It's more than just a game; it's a source of laughter and happiness, proving that joy knows no age limits.

In my time, we believed that laughter was the best medicine. Well, I can confidently say that "Human Fall Flat" is a potent tonic for the soul. It keeps my heart young, my spirits high, and my wonder for the world alive

I've never played this game solo, nor do I intend to, but playing it with a friend or three is a very enjoyable experience.
It's pretty much a physics-based puzzle/platformer. Helping each other traverse the landscape and get past the puzzles.
There's room for a lot of co-operation and room for even more 'shenanigans', if that's your style of play.
The game can be tricky to get used to the controls, at least as far as newbies and casual gamers go, but if you've been gaming for years like I have, then it's pretty straight-forward.
I would even gladly have paid full-price for this game as there's a been a lot of new content, in the form of new maps, added since release for free, as updates.
When it's on sale, I'd say this is a Must-Buy.

This game... baffles me. A physics-based puzzle-platformer designed to be janky and frustrating, yet I continue to play the levels and get mad over the puzzles. Is it just my innate sense to get all the achievements and consider it 'finished' in mine eyes? Or do I enjoy my way of cruising through levels by infini-climbing walls? Perhaps it is the possibilities of the character creator, or the anger caused by the very same character when their hand gets stuck behind their head, or internally losing my mind when I fail again and again to pick up and keep upright the small objects? I'm not sure what keeps me playing; and with a sequel coming out I will definitely see myself buying it; and I'm aware most people, once getting mad at the game, would quit and go on with their lives. But this game has its grip on me in some shape or form. Human: Fall Flat sure got me.

I do recommend this game but it does not deserve to be Overwhelmingly Positive.

The game has a lot to offer. The physic's based puzzles are a fun challenge, the custom options for  models are great, and it's great to play with friends. IF they're sitting right next to you. It's certainly viable to play the game by yourself and still have fun, but the servers have Nintendo level control delays at any given moment. For a game that requires the player to maneuver with already floaty controls (that make the game fun...), bad server connection is the absolute worst (...if the server works). Half the people when you join a server kick you out, or you lose connection regardless of what the host does. The delays in the controls last a whole second and the couple times I tried to get this game to work with friends, their models weren't working, workshop levels weren't loading, or nothing was working as intended.

I still love this game regardless. The levels are challenging and very replayable, and if you have no friends to play with you can still host a server and wait for people join without the issue of bad connection. But for a game to be centered around co-op, and knowing that not everyone can play locally, the game should not have bad server connection.

Human: Fall Flat presents an exceptional multiplayer ragdoll game that offers an immersive and enjoyable experience. Notably, the game showcases captivating gameplay mechanics that involve tasks such as manipulating wires, breaking glass, and engaging in various interactive elements. Additionally, a unique feature allows players to manipulate their friends' avatars by dragging their heads, adding an element of lightheartedness and amusement to the overall gameplay dynamics. Human: Fall Flat stands as a remarkable multiplayer title, incorporating a range of entertaining gameplay mechanics and fostering an engaging cooperative experience.

Playing this game solo is an absolute delight, offering a challenging and immensely enjoyable experience. It pushes the boundaries of your cognitive abilities as you navigate the three-dimensional space and tackle mind-bending puzzles. You'll constantly find yourself engaging in creative problem-solving, whether it's climbing, pushing, or jumping your way through the diverse array of obstacles.

However, the true magic of this game lies in its multiplayer mode. When you gather your friends for a gaming session, the atmosphere becomes electrifying. It's as if a primal instinct takes over, transforming all of you into a boisterous pack of energetic apes. The cooperative gameplay turns into a whirlwind of chaotic and hilariously nonsensical actions, resulting in unforgettable moments of laughter and camaraderie. Whether you choose to conquer the game alone or embark on a wild multiplayer adventure, this game offers an experience that is truly one-of-a-kind.

[h1] Human Fall Flat - A Quirky and Physics-Based Puzzle Adventure [/h1]

Overall Rating: â˜…â˜…â˜…â˜…â˜†

Human Fall Flat, developed by No Brakes Games, is a quirky and physics-based puzzle adventure that offers a unique and entertaining gameplay experience. Players take on the role of Bob, a wobbly and whimsical character who must navigate through a series of challenging levels using his unconventional movement abilities and problem-solving skills.

Graphics: â˜…â˜…â˜…â˜†â˜†
The graphics in Human Fall Flat adopt a charming and minimalist art style that adds to the game's whimsical atmosphere. While the visuals may not be the most detailed or realistic, they suit the game's comedic and lighthearted tone. The physics-based animations of Bob and the interactive objects in the environment provide a sense of playfulness and unpredictability.

Gameplay: â˜…â˜…â˜…â˜…â˜†
The gameplay of Human Fall Flat revolves around controlling Bob's ragdoll-like character to solve physics-based puzzles. Players must manipulate objects, climb, swing, and jump through the levels, all while navigating the challenges presented by the game's unique physics engine. The controls can feel intentionally clumsy, adding to the game's humor and creating hilarious situations as Bob stumbles and flops his way through the obstacles.

Puzzles and Challenges: â˜…â˜…â˜…â˜…â˜†
Human Fall Flat offers a variety of puzzles and challenges that require creative thinking and experimentation. Each level presents a different environment with its own set of obstacles and puzzles to overcome. From using objects to create makeshift ramps to swinging on ropes and levers, players must find unique solutions to progress. The open-ended nature of the puzzles encourages exploration and invites players to approach challenges in their own way.

Cooperative Multiplayer: â˜…â˜…â˜…â˜…â˜†
One of the standout features of Human Fall Flat is its cooperative multiplayer mode, allowing players to team up with friends or other online players to tackle the puzzles together. The multiplayer aspect adds an additional layer of fun and laughter as players collaborate or unintentionally hinder each other's progress, leading to amusing and unpredictable moments.

Replayability: â˜…â˜…â˜…â˜†â˜†
While Human Fall Flat may not have extensive replay value in terms of storyline or branching paths, its physics-based gameplay and cooperative multiplayer mode offer some replayability. The joy of experimenting with the game's physics, discovering new ways to solve puzzles, and the potential for different experiences with friends make it worth revisiting.

Conclusion:
Human Fall Flat delivers a unique and entertaining experience with its quirky physics-based gameplay, charming visuals, and cooperative multiplayer mode. The game's humor, puzzle design, and open-ended approach provide a refreshing break from traditional puzzle-solving games. Whether playing solo or with friends, Human Fall Flat offers plenty of laughter-filled moments and enjoyable challenges, making it a worthwhile adventure for those seeking a lighthearted and creative gaming experience.

Human: Fall Flat is an absolutely delightful and hilarious physics-based puzzle game that will have you laughing, strategizing, and thoroughly entertained from start to finish. This quirky gem of a game combines innovative gameplay mechanics with a charming art style to create an experience that is as enjoyable to watch as it is to play.

One of the standout features of Human: Fall Flat is its intuitive and realistic physics system. Controlling your wobbly, customizable character feels both challenging and comical, leading to countless moments of unexpected hilarity. The unpredictable nature of the physics adds an element of surprise to each puzzle, allowing for a wide range of creative and often unconventional solutions.

The game's puzzles are cleverly designed, requiring you to think outside the box and experiment with the environment. From manipulating objects to navigating treacherous platforms, each level presents a unique and engaging challenge. Human: Fall Flat encourages creativity and problem-solving, allowing players to tackle puzzles in multiple ways, leading to a sense of accomplishment and satisfaction.

The open-ended nature of the game gives you the freedom to approach each level at your own pace and in your own style. Whether you prefer a more methodical and strategic approach or enjoy embracing the chaos and embracing hilarious mishaps, Human: Fall Flat accommodates various playstyles, making it accessible to players of all skill levels.

The game's charming and whimsical art style adds to its overall appeal. The squishy, dough-like characters and colorful, dreamlike environments create a visually delightful experience. The attention to detail in the character animations and the seamless integration of the physics system make for a visually immersive and engaging gameplay.

Furthermore, Human: Fall Flat offers an enjoyable multiplayer experience. Cooperative play allows you to team up with friends, leading to even more hilarious and unpredictable moments as you attempt to coordinate your actions. The collaborative nature of the multiplayer mode adds an extra layer of fun and encourages laughter-filled play sessions with friends.

The replay value of Human: Fall Flat is exceptional. With multiple levels to explore and the freedom to experiment with different approaches and strategies, the game offers hours of entertainment. Additionally, the game's active community regularly creates and shares custom levels, expanding the game's content and providing endless opportunities for new puzzles and challenges.

In conclusion, Human: Fall Flat is a delightful and charming physics-based puzzle game that offers a refreshing and entertaining experience. Its intuitive physics system, clever puzzles, and whimsical art style create a captivating world where laughter and creative problem-solving go hand in hand. Whether you're playing solo or with friends, Human: Fall Flat guarantees an unforgettable adventure filled with laughter, surprises, and a whole lot of fun.

My name is Walter Hartwell White. I live at 308 Negra Arroyo Lane, Albuquerque, New Mexico, 87104. This is my confession. If you're watching this tape, I'm probably deadâ€“ murdered by my brother-in-law, Hank Schrader. Hank has been building a meth empire for over a year now, and using me as his chemist. Shortly after my 50th birthday, he asked that I use my chemistry knowledge to cook methamphetamine, which he would then sell using connections that he made through his career with the DEA. I was... astounded. I... I always thought Hank was a very moral man, and I was particularly vulnerable at the time â€“ something he knew and took advantage of. I was reeling from a cancer diagnosis that was poised to bankrupt my family. Hank took me in on a ride-along and showed me just how much money even a small meth operation could make. And I was weak. I didn't want my family to go into financial ruin, so I agreed. Hank had a partner, a businessman named Gustavo Fring. Hank sold me into servitude to this man. And when I tried to quit, Fring threatened my family. I didn't know where to turn. Eventually, Hank and Fring had a falling-out. Things escalated. Fring was able to arrange â€“ uh, I guess... I guess you call it a "hit" â€“ on Hank, and failed, but Hank was seriously injured. And I wound up paying his medical bills, which amounted to a little over $177,000. Upon recovery, Hank was bent on revenge. Working with a man named Hector Salamanca, he plotted to kill Fring. The bomb that he used was built by me, and he gave me no option in it. I have
often contemplated suicide, but I'm a coward. I wanted to go to the police, but I was frightened. Hank had risen to become the head of the Albuquerque DEA. To keep me in line, he took my children. For three months, he kept them. My wife had no idea of my criminal activities, and was horrified to learn what I had done. I was in hell. I hated myself for what I had brought upon my family. Recently, I tried once again to quit, and in response, he gave me this. [Walt points to the bruise on his face left by Hank in "Blood Money."] I can't take this anymore. I live in fear every day that Hank will kill me, or worse, hurt my family. All I could think to do was to make this video and hope that the world will finally see this man for what he really is.

Review: â˜…â˜…â˜…â˜…â˜…

Human: Fall Flat is an absolute gem of a game that deserves all the praise it receives on Steam! From the moment I started playing, I was hooked by its unique blend of physics-based puzzles and whimsical charm. This game is a true delight for anyone who enjoys a good laugh and a fun, lighthearted adventure.

One of the standout features of Human: Fall Flat is its physics-based gameplay. Controlling Bob, the endearing and slightly clumsy protagonist, is an absolute blast. The controls may seem simple at first, but they lend themselves to a world of hilarious possibilities. From swinging on ropes to climbing obstacles, each action is subject to the whims of the game's physics engine, leading to unexpected and often side-splitting outcomes. It's impossible not to laugh when you and your friends are flailing around, trying to coordinate your movements and failing spectacularly!

The level design in Human: Fall Flat is fantastic. Each level presents a new and imaginative environment to explore, with its own set of puzzles to solve. I was constantly surprised by the creativity and variety of the challenges. Whether it's navigating a construction site, scaling a snowy mountain, or even exploring dreamlike fantasy realms, the game keeps things fresh and exciting throughout.

But what truly sets Human: Fall Flat apart is its charming art style and endearing protagonist. Bob is a lovable, blob-like character with customizable features that allow you to make him your own. The visual design is simple yet captivating, with vibrant colors and a whimsical atmosphere that adds to the game's overall charm. The soundtrack perfectly complements the gameplay, enhancing the immersion and creating an enjoyable experience.

The multiplayer aspect of Human: Fall Flat is an absolute blast. Whether you're playing with friends or joining a random online game, the laughter and chaos that ensue are unparalleled. Working together to solve puzzles or simply messing around and wreaking havoc, the multiplayer mode adds another layer of fun and unpredictability.

In conclusion, Human: Fall Flat is a must-play game that delivers endless laughs, creative puzzles, and an overall heartwarming experience. Its physics-based gameplay, charming art style, and multiplayer mode make it an absolute joy to play, whether solo or with friends. If you're looking for a light-hearted adventure filled with laughter, this game is an absolute gem that deserves a spot in your Steam library!

***This review is definitely not written by ChatGPT***

Human Fall Flat is a physics-based puzzle game that provides a unique and hilarious experience for players. The game revolves around controlling a clumsy, wobbly character named Bob as he navigates through various puzzles and obstacles.

The game's physics-based gameplay is one of the highlights of the game, and it is truly impressive how well the game engine simulates Bob's movements and the world around him. It can be a bit challenging to get used to the controls, but once you do, it adds to the game's humor and charm.

The puzzles in Human Fall Flat are inventive, and the game constantly introduces new mechanics and challenges as you progress. The game is also incredibly open-ended, which allows for players to come up with creative solutions to the puzzles.

The game's graphics and sound design are simple yet effective, and the game's visual style adds to the game's charm. The game also has an excellent multiplayer mode, which allows you to play with up to 8 players online, which can be an absolute blast with friends.

Overall, I thoroughly enjoyed playing Human Fall Flat. The game's quirky humor, inventive puzzles, and physics-based gameplay make it a unique and memorable experience. It's definitely worth checking out if you're looking for a fun and challenging puzzle game with a touch of humor.

Human: Fall Flat is a game that puts you in control of a wobbly, clumsy character, navigating through a series of puzzles and challenges. It's a game that's full of laughter and silliness, but also requires some serious brainpower. Let's take a closer look at the pros and cons of this charming game:

Pros:
[list]
[*]The game's physics-based gameplay is unique and engaging, as you control a character that wobbles and stumbles through a variety of obstacles. It's a lot of fun to watch your character stumble around, and it adds an extra layer of challenge to the puzzles.
[*]The game's graphics are charming and whimsical, with a cartoonish art style that's full of personality. It's a visual treat that will make you smile.
[*]The game's puzzles are challenging but rewarding, with a variety of obstacles to overcome and solutions to discover. It's a game that will keep your brain engaged and your creativity flowing.
[*]The game's co-op mode is a blast, allowing you to play with friends and work together to solve puzzles and challenges. It's a great way to bond and have fun with others.
[/list]

Cons:
[list]
[*]The game's controls can be a bit finicky at times, especially when it comes to moving and manipulating objects. It may take some time to get used to the character's wobbly movements.
[*]The game's difficulty level can be unbalanced, with some puzzles feeling too easy and others feeling nearly impossible. This can lead to frustration and a feeling of unfairness.
[*]The game's replay value is a bit low, as once you've solved the puzzles, there's not much reason to go back and play through again.
[/list]

Overall, Human: Fall Flat is a charming and engaging game that's perfect for anyone who loves puzzles and physics-based gameplay. With its unique mechanics, whimsical graphics, and challenging puzzles, it's a game that's worth playing. Just be prepared for a bit of a learning curve and some frustration along the way.

This game is way better than it looks.  Your avatar is programmed with a randomized leaning axis mechanic that makes all your movements much more difficult than they'd normally be.  Essentially the developer said: "Hey, you know that gaming thing called 'controls' and how everyone is trying to make the best controller scheme possible for their video game?  We're going to do the opposite and give you the worst controls possible.  Then we're going to have you do the simplest mundane tasks imaginable, such as rowing a boat or bowling, and we'll see how far you get."  And you know what -- it works!

Its essentially a puzzle game where the puzzle is simple movement and your buddies keep throwing you off cliffs.  It's silly fun!

I suppose I should warn you though: if you play with someone that refuses to wait for people, you'll get teleported and miss out on stuff.  Might want to leave that guy off your invite list.

Human: Fall Flat is a hilarious and physics-based puzzle game that offers a unique and entertaining gameplay experience. The game features a lovable and clumsy character named Bob, who must navigate through a variety of obstacles and challenges.

One of the standout features of Human: Fall Flat is its physics-based gameplay. The game's controls are intentionally clunky, which adds to the game's humor and challenge. Players must use careful planning and creative thinking to solve the game's puzzles, which range from simple to complex.

The game's visuals are also impressive. The game features a minimalist and stylized art style that's both charming and immersive. The game's environments are well-designed, with a variety of different settings to explore.

The game's sound design is also noteworthy. The game's soundtrack is whimsical and fitting, with a variety of different themes and styles that match the game's tone. The game's sound effects are also well-done, adding to the overall immersion of the game.

Overall, Human: Fall Flat is a fun and entertaining puzzle game that offers a unique and enjoyable gameplay experience. The game's physics-based controls, visuals, and sound design make it a great addition to any gamer's library.

I deeply regret buying Human: Fall Flat. The game is marketed as having cross-play between Xbox and PC, but this is completely false. PC and Xbox players cannot play together. Furthermore, even playing the game solo was a terrible experience. While the soundtrack on the loading screen is nice, finding a good match is difficult due to the lack of servers and players.

But even if you do manage to find a game, you may end up waiting for 20 minutes in a loading screen only to find yourself stuck. And even when you do join a game, it may not be what you were expecting. I joined a lobby that ended up being a roleplay server, with no indication of that in the lobby name or description. And to make matters worse, the other players were talking about "e-dating" and having weird personal conversations.

The game lacks any real objectives or sense of purpose, and the gameplay is a letdown. I was hoping for an arcade/cartoony feel with fun minigames, but instead, I found myself disappointed and wishing I could get my money back. I normally do not write reviews, but I had to warn others about this game's false marketing and lackluster gameplay. Don't waste your money on Human: Fall Flat.

Do you want to get launched off the edge you were so desperately trying to clime? Do you like having your character fling around for no reason? Do you like it when your entire character moves because the camera makes them pivot around a point that is slightly in front of the character? Then this is the game for you! This game is really fun when it comes down to it's puzzles! Although they are really easy. The hard stuff is the puzzles that involve movement, because the physics in the game are so unbelievably bad that if you aren't extremely careful and take like 1-2 minuets making sure your legs are up, your back is straight, and more before you let go you will get launched forwards. Which sounds like fun! If it didn't completely fuck you over in almost half of the games puzzles. And if you body is slightly twisted in a way you can't fix, you are just going to get launched no matter what. I would recommend this game if you like rage games, as it's more that than actual puzzle. But if you want a puzzle game? This isn't it, keep looking.

If you're looking for a game that will make you laugh until your sides hurt, look no further than Human: Fall Flat on Steam! This game is a hilarious and wacky adventure that will have you falling flat on your face - literally - and loving every minute of it.One of the best things about Human: Fall Flat is its physics engine, which allows you to control your character's movements in a hilariously clumsy way. You'll stumble, bumble, and flop your way through each level, trying to solve puzzles and reach your objectives despite your character's complete lack of coordination.But don't worry, falling flat on your face is all part of the fun! In fact, it's almost more satisfying to fail spectacularly than it is to succeed. And when you do finally figure out a particularly tricky puzzle or make it through a difficult level, you'll feel like a true champion.The graphics in Human: Fall Flat are also top-notch, with colorful and whimsical environments that will transport you to a world of pure joy and silliness. And the sound effects and music are just as delightful, adding to the overall sense of playfulness and fun.Overall, if you're looking for a game that will lift your spirits and put a big, goofy smile on your face, Human: Fall Flat is the perfect choice. Whether you're playing alone or with friends, you're sure to have a blast stumbling and tumbling your way through each level. So grab a controller, get ready to fall flat, and prepare to have the time of your life!

Human Fall Flat engaged me from the very start. Completing all of the game's puzzles is challenging yet hilarious, and there are often multiple different ways to solve each one. While Human Fall Flat is definitely best to play with a friend, it still delivers as a solo adventure.

Human Fall Flat is an absolute gem of a game that is guaranteed to provide you with hours of laughter and fun. The game mechanics are brilliantly designed, and the physics-based puzzles will keep you engaged and entertained for hours on end.

The game's graphics are stunning, and the beautifully designed environments are a delight to explore. The levels are varied and well-crafted, and each one provides a unique challenge that will test your skills and creativity.

The controls are simple and intuitive, making it easy to pick up and play for anyone. However, mastering them is an entirely different story, and it is what makes the game so much fun. The game is designed to be played with friends, and the co-op mode is an absolute blast. Working together to solve puzzles and overcome obstacles is a great way to bond and have fun with your friends.

Overall, Human Fall Flat is a fantastic game that I would highly recommend to anyone. It is a game that is guaranteed to put a smile on your face and keep you entertained for hours on end. The developers have done an excellent job creating a unique and fun experience that is accessible to everyone. If you're looking for a game that is challenging, fun, and just downright hilarious, then Human Fall Flat is the perfect game for you.

The puzzles are very straightforward, and this is by design, because the difficulty is not in the puzzle but in the movement required to get somewhere or transport an item. The mechanics are deceptively simple, very easy to learn but hard to master. The possibilities even with the simple controls are pretty much endless, and with some experience the movement starts to feel lifelike and pretty soon you'll be doing all sorts of complex acrobatics. 10/10 try it with a friend

My first experience with this game was one of disappointment and dread. I spent my last $20 to my name thinking this was gang beasts and needless to say I was crushed. To my ignorance I discovered a silver lining, my father in law (who held disdain towards me) owned this game and it was the perfect opportunity to make a good impression. The first time we played was incredible, we worked together completing puzzles and i could already tell that he was warming up tom me. I told my wife about it and she was so happy. Eventually we were playing everyday for hours on end enjoying each others company. one day I logged on after my wife had gone to sleep and i noticed he was offline (this was out of the ordinary). But just then I hear a knock at the door and to my disbelief it was my father in law. He was dressed as my favorite character from the game and told me he wanted to play the game IRL. My wife woke up the next morning and found us in my sons bed (who was at his friends house that night). Fast forward 2 years later me and my father in law are living out our days in Indonesia. we are both unemployed and keeping ourselves afloat by siphoning my children's collage fund. Things worked out great and I owe it all to Human Fall Flat

Human: Fall Flat is an incredibly fun and unique puzzle platformer game that is sure to keep you entertained for hours on end. The game's simple yet charming graphics, combined with its physics-based gameplay mechanics, create an immersive and enjoyable experience.

What sets Human: Fall Flat apart from other platformer games is its focus on physics-based puzzles. Players must use their creativity and problem-solving skills to navigate through each level and complete the objectives. The game's physics engine allows for a wide variety of creative solutions, and the levels are designed to encourage experimentation and exploration.

The game also features a highly customizable character, allowing players to create their own unique avatars and express themselves in the game world. The ability to customize your character is a nice touch and adds an extra layer of immersion to the game.

Another aspect of the game that I love is the multiplayer mode. Playing with friends can add a whole new level of fun to the game, as you work together to solve puzzles and navigate through the levels. The multiplayer mode is seamless and easy to use, making it a great option for online play.

Overall, I highly recommend Human: Fall Flat to anyone looking for a fun and engaging puzzle platformer game. With its unique physics-based gameplay, charming graphics, and multiplayer mode, it's a game that you won't want to put down.

I am a 45 yo mother, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single mother to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2022 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and world and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my husband had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

Human Fall Flat is a physics-based puzzle platformer game developed and published by No Brakes Games. The game's protagonist is a customizable humanoid character with floppy, exaggerated movements and animations, creating a unique and entertaining gaming experience.

One of the strengths of Human Fall Flat is its simple and intuitive controls. The player can move the character's arms and legs individually, allowing for a wide range of movements and actions, from running and jumping to carrying and throwing objects. This, combined with the game's loose physics, creates a sense of unpredictability and humor, as the character's movements are often comically awkward.

The game features a variety of levels set in different environments, including construction sites, castles, and dreamlike landscapes. Each level is filled with obstacles, puzzles, and secrets to be discovered, requiring the player to use their wits and creativity to progress. The game also features a local multiplayer mode, allowing up to eight players to collaborate or compete on the same levels.

In terms of graphics and sound, Human Fall Flat is well-designed and aesthetically pleasing. The game's whimsical and cartoonish art style is well-suited to the game's tone and theme, and the sound effects and music effectively create a sense of atmosphere.

Overall, Human Fall Flat is a fun and entertaining game that is well worth playing for fans of puzzle platformers. Its simple controls and humorous take on physics make it a standout in the genre, and its variety of levels and multiplayer mode ensure that players will have plenty to keep them engaged. Highly recommended for those who enjoy a good challenge and a good laugh.

Skydiving is parachuting from an airplane for fun. Skydiving can be done individually and with groups of people. Training is required. Unlike most paratroopers, skydivers often wait until they are low, before opening the parachute. The jump can also be made from a helicopter or a balloon that is high enough in the sky. Skydiving can be an exciting sport.

Skydiving includes free falling (usually from an airplane) through the air prior to opening a parachute. Typically skydives are carried out from around 4,000m (or 12,500ft) offering 40 to 50 seconds of freefall time. Longer free fall times can be achieved by exiting an aircraft at altitudes much higher than 4,000m, but very high jumps require pressurized air within the aircraft, and bottled oxygen for the diver.
During a skydive, total freedom and control of the air can be enjoyed as well as many complex and spectacular maneuvers including flat turns, somersaults and formation skydiving. Skydiving can be enjoyed either as an individual - doing solo(alone) jumps - or as part of a team carrying out formation skydiving. Generally, the term â€˜skydiveâ€™ refers to the time spent in freefall from exiting an aircraft to deploying a parachute but skydiving does include some disciplines such as accuracy landings and canopy formation flying which concentrate on the time spent once a canopy has been deployed

I am glad that I have made this purchase. I might have left the game running, but the 10 minutes when I was playing it brought me an immense amount of joy. It's dark message brings light on an unanswered question: What is the meaning of life? This wondrously developed video game answers this head-scratching question in the most artistically beautiful way which will leave you pondering for the rest of your days. Do not cry. Do not give up. Believe in yourself and break free.  Don't look back. Grow and change. Live life to it's fullest. This is what Gang Beasts taught me.

I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single farther to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2021 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So I decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.
