This is how I feel after drinking two sojus. Jokes aside, this game is phenomenal. The controls are ass, but that's how the controls are supposed to be, so that's not bad. By ass, I just mean the character you control just feels like a drunk baby with stubby ass legs. I love the levels and how they try to have a different approach to each level. There are also the community levels which are just awesome, the developers just know what they are doing. I do have a minor complaint about the music, because it's kinda short, and then you're just left with your own thoughts. Picture this: you enter a level regarding construction and power plants, and this whole John Williams - esque soundtrack plays for 2 minutes at most, and then it's just silence. Playing with friends is also fun, but you can definitely tell its more meant for single player fun.

Overall good game. I can always appreciate more maps and customizable models to be added.
I do have an issue with the painter being a pain to work with (such as paintstrokes appearing on the back of the model, where it wasn't intended to be) and the fact that so many public servers have a subpar connection these days.

Before playing this game on Steam, I played this on both my Xbox and my PS4 around 2018 and tried my best to 100% the game despite some broken achievements at the time on the level Castle. The game is very fun and I have at least put around 200 hours into this game total on all of my platforms and I even used to speed run the game at the time when Aztec was still the final level of the game. 

There was always a bug at the time with the online mode where if you weren't the host, you'd have sometimes a 2-10 second movement delay. This was caused by my guess being host sided servers, or something. In 2022, almost 2023, games that are still supported shouldn't be having this issue and should have stable game-play for all users. It's a shame because this bug has been around since when the game first came out 6 years ago, and it's a shame to see that it's not fixed despite this game receiving large amounts of success.

It's one of my favourite games ever, but I wouldn't recommend it just due to this reason for online players. :<
this game makes the bois act up

This game saved my life.

I am 27.

My ex-wife and I have a daughter together, and adopted our son together. They are now both 4 years old.

When we were going through our separation, I found myself lost and miserable. I was self destructive. I got so mad one day from everything spiraling out of my control that I punched some concrete in a moment of overwhelming emotion. That caused me to break my 5th metacarpal in my right hand... my working hand... my games hand.. the hand that I held and carried my children to bed with.. The hand I desperately needed to make sure I could continue to provide.

After learning of the severity of my self-inflicted damage, I was borderline suicidal. Keep in mind that just a few months before this, I was the happiest man with no history of depression or anxiety. I have never had fits of rage, or been one to break down and cry, but I was in a low spot that just really buried me from being able to see the light on the other side.

Having nothing better to do, I searched for a game I could play, ONE HANDED while I recovered. I somehow stumbled upon this game and read some of the reviews. I decided that it had to be worth a shot... I must admit, I didn't beat the game, or play nearly as long as some of you. In fact, I may have only played this game a day or two.. With that being said, after doing so, I had a new found joy and hope for life. I was able to put behind me the pain and suffering that had been cast over me. I was able to experience other peoples joy and happiness. I was able to see the fruits of my "labor". I relaxed for 5 â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ing minutes to this music long enough to realize that I was going to be okay.

After coming to that realization, I turned the game off, and I went back to work. It hurt my hand like hell but I was motivated. I stopped feeling so damn sorry for myself, and I became the father I needed to be in that moment, not the weak boy I was behaving as.

Today, I am close friend with my kids mother. We don't fight, or argue, or say hurtful things to each other. We are parents, and friends.

I now have 3 kids. My third child is, wait for it, ALSO 4 YEARS OLD. The woman I am with was going through a very similar situation at the time of my own separation, and we just stumbled in to each others life unexpectedly. We have been in a relationship for a year now, and are very happy together.

Moral of the story, you never know what life holds in store for you, and if I would have given up when all the odds were stacked against me, I wouldn't be where I am today. This silly little game helped me realize that.

Human Fall Flat is a game that is supposed to be fun and entertaining, especially when played with friends. However, for me, it just reminded me of how lonely and isolated I am.

I don't have any friends to play this game with, and so I ended up playing it alone. It was just a reminder of how much I miss having someone to laugh and have fun with.

The game itself is okay, but it's not something that can make up for the lack of human connection in my life. I found myself getting frustrated and depressed as I played, feeling like I was just going through the motions and not really enjoying it.

In short, Human Fall Flat is a game that is best played with friends. Unfortunately, I don't have any, and so it just ended up being a sad and depressing experience for me.

10/10

If your looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if your looking for an outstanding pie recipe you've come to the right place.

Ingredients:
1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter
2. 1/2 cup white sugar
3. 1/2 cup brown sugar
4. 1/4 cup water
5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon
6. 1 pinch salt
7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced
8. 1 pastry for double-crust pie

Directions:
1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).
2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside.
3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices.
4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal.
5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust.
6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.

I am a 44 year old father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my son, who is now 14. My son recently started this game and in less than a week, he had already played for over 20 hours. This was terrible for me, as it was already hard enough for me to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching videos on Tiktok. So I decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, did the tutorial but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought my son and I closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

I am a 43 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just, watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. loaded into the game, made my character and world and started playing but I was stuck on what you were supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he helped me. Loved it as it was the best time had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

I enjoy the concept and game play very much, but the shaky camera makes me enable to play for more than 10 minutes at a time (and the jittering frame time definitely makes it worse). I've never had any 3d motion sickness except this game. If you are like me, your best bet is to make the FOP larger than 110 degrees and keep jumping as much as possible (you also move faster this way). Your camera will not shake when you keep jumping, and that's the like peaceful time I had. Surely you can't always keep jumping, and the nausea prevents me from solving the puzzles.

If your looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if your looking for an outstanding pie recipe you've come to the right place.

Ingredients:
1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter
2. 1/2 cup white sugar
3. 1/2 cup brown sugar
4. 1/4 cup water
5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon
6. 1 pinch salt
7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced
8. 1 pastry for double-crust pie

Directions:
1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).
2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside.
3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices.
4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal.
5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust.
6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing. ;)

You know how 3-D Platformers can sometimes be really hard to control? Well, this game takes that problem and makes it a feature. That might sound terrible, but the point of this game isn't precise maneuvering, but instead watching your character bumble about haphazardly as you grapple every obstacle. It's a fun time. Trying to accomplish things as a faceless drunk is very entertaining, especially if you've got someone else to play with. Multiplayer makes things even better, trying to coordinate with someone else while you're trying to coordinate yourself makes for a great experience. They keep adding new levels every few months and probably will for the forseeable future. Workshop levels are also worth giving a shot.
The game is probably better without it, but I still miss when you could just climb straight up a wall by sort of spam clicking with the right timing.

Human: Fall Flat is a Gang Beasts-like experience. Youâ€™ll have to solve puzzles in order to finish the levels that you are set in. 
This game is so funny, itâ€™s amazing! I donâ€™t have a lot of hours in this game but I guarantee you itâ€™s really funny. Thereâ€™s quite a few levels but youâ€™ll run through them pretty quickly, but, itâ€™s tons of fun! If you plan on playing this game with friends, PUT THIS GAME IN YOUR SHOPPING CART RIGHT NOW. Otherwise, GO FIND FRIENDS AND BUY THIS GAME AND PLAY IT WITH THEM.

I finally start to learn how interesting this game is. Official levels are so well designed that there is always some cheat path that leads you directly to the end via wall climbing or super jumping. But if you really want to dig deeper into the game and try to get all the achievements, you will start to appreciate how puzzles are put up together. It urges you to think outside the box, [spoiler]to break glass with rubber boats, to break a wall with wooden box or just another stone, to step on the tip of a tree or to step on a rolling ball[/spoiler]. And there are more paths for you to explore. 
It also provides players easy ways to make your own map. While crafting their game with unity engine provided by others, some of them might grow to be excellent game makers in the future. And I love how the community of Human Fall Flat to keep on creating to inject vim and vigor to the game to this date.
I just like the new maps added to the game. It's nice to constantly revisit the game and find new elements. Shout out to all the people dedicated to bringing new features.

everything about this game is irritating. you have to fight with the controls to do the most basic stuff. i can't even focus on the puzzles because trying to execute any idea is ten minutes of repeating the same jump while swinging the camera around to move my arms, or trying repeatedly to smash something through a piece of glass with enough force (which is determined by how fast i move the camera, of course). this is the first non-vr game that's made me nauseous. there are also a lot of situations where you can ruin the intended way to clear something, and have to find a tedious workaround. it's stupid and i won't play any more. it's not low effort, it's original, there are good things about it, but i hate it.

Ther real reason why I'm doing a negative review is because Linux support just dropped [b]silently[/b] a few years back and then the devs only said anything because of this post: https://steamcommunity.com/app/477160/discussions/0/1735468693704602016/

I do understand their reason, but I don't think taking out like that was a good move afterall. Linux users already have so much to deal with without Proton. 

I wish Steam had a Informative review instead of positive and negative since it's more an info to be shared than a review itself. 
Just be aware of any game from No Brakes Games after that if you're a Linux user.

Perfect game for introverts. For those that like exploring and doing virtual hiking in unknown worlds. Platforms can be tricky when dealing with lag. Sometimes not many public rooms in my area. Otherwise, very peaceful game.

WARNING : Good but gets incredibly frustrating. Some seriously hard puzzles/problems, mostly in a good way. This makes the game quite compulsive. You will hate your character though - sort of wobbly bag of pale white jelly and always slightly unstable. Just what you need for serious 3D platforming. Actually sometimes this adds a little real challenge and subtlety to the game in a good way.

Only real negative is the save system or lack of one.. Uses checkpoints which actually work okay while in a level, but sometimes eventually you want to take a break and leave. Later levels get absolutely huge and each takes hours to play. When you reload and continue you restart back at the last checkpoint - the hell comes because everything you've done in the level resets. 
Played single player only.
This is a very fun game with friends. We laughed super hard and played for hours.

I am a 52 year old father, probably one of the oldest people playing. I am a single father to my son, who is now 14. My son recently started playing and in less than a week, he had already played for over 20 hours. This was terrible for me because it was already hard enough for me to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching videos on Youtube. So I decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my son for help, and together we spent hours playing . I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my son since my wife had died. Steam has ever since brought me and my son closer again, and now we actually spend time together outside the house as well. reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both my son and I many happy memories.

Human Fall Flat is not just a delightful co-op puzzle game.  It's a promise that there can be games with rock-solid netcode and physics.  No warping.  Hardly any clipping.  Things stack, things unstack, even when players are interacting with them.  Are the physics perfect?  No, you can walk in certain ways to drive boats around, for example.  But they are SO GOOD.

Fun physics puzzles, although the open nature of the worlds leads to me spending a lot of time on something that isn't actually part of the puzzle. This game is pretty wonky - the movement of your character is very unique; you control all your limbs individually which makes you look like you're drunk all the time.
